Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: High Dimensional Multivariate Analysis
Award.AbstractNarration:
Classical multivariate analyses are typically designed for fixed dimensional data, and are often not applicable, even invalid, for high-dimensional data. Analysis of modern high-dimensional data call for novel multivariate statistical approaches in the "large-p, small n" paradigm. This proposal consists of three broad objectives aiming to establish a set of multivariate inferential procedures that are adaptive to high dimensionality, and can accommodate a wide range of model and dependence structures. The investigators will develop new thresholding methods to improve the power performance of the tests for high dimensional means and covariance when the signals are sparse and faint. They also propose bandwidth estimators for the state of the art banding and tapering estimators for covariances, and hence make these two estimation approaches practical. The project will also develop tests for nonparametric functions of high-dimensional covariates in partially linear models.

The multivariate testing procedures obtained from the proposed projects will be readily applicable in selecting gene-sets which are associated with phenotype variations, or responsive to certain treatments in the forms of having different means or covariance. The successful application in gene-set analysis will enhance our understanding of gene regulations at a biological meaningful pathway level. The research will also improve the applications of multivariate analysis in biology, marketing research, and financial risk management.

Institution.Name: Iowa State University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project has obtained a set of important results regarding high dimensional statistics analysis.  It has deviced a set of high dimensional procedures that are adaptive to extreme high dimensional data. This includes a careful study on a L_2 norm based thresholding test procedures for means as in Zhong, Chen and Xu (2013). It shows that by applying multiple thresholding  on a L_2 norm based test the optimal detection boundary for multivariate Gaussian data can be obtained without the Gaussian assumption. This is an important results after Donoho and Jin (2004)'s higher criticism test.  Qiu, Chen and Nettleton (2017, AoS) extend the thresholding approach to detect signals in the MLEs in the generalized linear model. This largely broadens the scope of the thresholding approach beyond the sample means.  Peng, Chen and Zhou (2016) considered a refinement of the high dimensional covariance testing proposed by Chen, Zhang and Zhong (2010) by applying the banding operation of Bickel and Levina (2008) to enhance the power performance of the test. 

 

For statistical inference for high dimensional generalized linear model, Guo and Chen (2016, JRSSB) considers testing for the regression coefficient vector, and has found the impact of the unbounded link function in the generalized linear model on the performance of an early test proposed by Goeman et al. (2011). The paper proposed a test procedure that is immuned by the boundedness of the link function.  

The project also obtains new results regarding high dimensional matrix completion in the presence of linear covariates.  The work is published as Mao, Chen and Wong (2017, JASA). 

 


Last Modified: 11/30/2017
Modified by: Song X Chen
